p: The major constituent of extracts and EO used in traditional medicines as an antimicrobial agent is p-cymene [ 41]. However, in this study, p-cymene exhibited the weakest antibacterial activity against S. aureus and E. coli [ 42]. Contrarily, limonene exhibited moderate antibacterial activity against these bacteria [ 43], while linalool exhibited strong antimicrobial activity [ 44]. It is well known that many plants exert their beneficial effects through the additive or synergistic action of several chemical compounds acting at single or multiple target sites [ 45]. The results from this study suggest that the combination effects of these compounds ( p-cymene, limonene and linalool) in S. kitaibelii EO had antibacterial enhancement (synergistic or additive effects) against tested bacteria ( S. aureus and E. coli). Further investigations into this topic need to be conducted.
